isis.stitle: VT 365 Diesel Engine - 2004 Model Year - POWER CYLINDERS - Removal - Preliminary Checks

note.para: Before removing any piston and connecting rod assemblies, piston protrusion should be evaluated. This will help identify bent or twisted connecting rods.
Before checking piston protrusion, make sure the crankcase deck surface is flat and level. See .

Piston protrusion readings are done at the 3 and 9 o'clock positions. These positions are in line with the piston pin, removing the rocking movement of the piston at any other position of measurement.

step1.para: Check piston protrusion above crankcase as follows:

step2.para: Zero dial indicator gauge on crankcase deck surface.
Position dial indicator tip over the piston head at 3 o'clock.

Bar the crankshaft around in the direction of normal rotation to raise the piston to its maximum outward protrusion at cylinder top dead center (TDC). Read this maximum protrusion on the dial indicator.
Reposition dial indicator tip on piston head at 9 o'clock.
Bar crankshaft around to raise the piston to its maximum protrusion. Read the maximum protrusion on the dial indicator.
Record reading, and then average the two readings. Replace piston and piston rod as required.

figure.caption: Side clearance check for connecting rod

step1.para: Use a feeler gauge to check connecting rod side clearance as follows:

step2.para: Pry apart a pair of connecting rods on a crankshaft rod journal. Insert largest possible feeler gauge between the connecting rods to check clearance.
Repeat for each pair of connecting rods on each crankshaft rod journal and compare with specification .

note.para: Lack of clearance could indicate a damaged rod or a rod bearing out of position. Excessive clearance may require replacement of rods or crankshaft. Correct as required.

caution.para: To prevent engine damage, check for carbon ridge on top of the cylinder bore, before removing the rod and piston assemblies.

step1.para: Scrape carbon ridge from top of cylinder bore, if necessary.
Rotate crankshaft to position journals for removal of connecting rod assemblies. Mark connecting rod locations.

caution.para: To prevent engine damage, check connecting rod bolts for binding. If bolts are binding, check thread condition during inspection.

step1.para: Remove two connecting rod bolts and connecting rod cap.
Remove piston and connecting rod assemblies from crankcase as follows:

step2.para: Rotate engine to a vertical position.
Use a wooden or plastic handle and push piston and rod assembly from cylinder bore.
Once piston rings are free of cylinder bore, remove piston and connecting rod assembly from crankcase.

caution.para: To prevent engine damage, make sure each connecting rod and cap is stamped, marked, or tagged as a matched set.
This engine uses fractured connecting rods. Do not alter or damage the fractured mating surfaces of rod and cap.

step1.para: When removed, make sure matching connecting rod and cap numbers stay together as a set. A cap from one connecting rod is not interchangeable with any other connecting rod.

figure.caption: Offset for incorrect rod cap assembly

step1.para: The rod cap can only be correctly installed on the connecting rod if it is oriented in the correct direction.

item.para: If the rod cap is reversed during assembly of the connecting rod, an obvious offset will be seen at the mating surfaces.
If the connecting rod assembly is installed on the crankshaft in this manner, the connecting rod must be replaced.

step1.para: Check the crankpin fillets for damage.

item.para: If crankpin fillets are damaged, replace crankshaft.
